column1: Mandalay ( or ; Burmese: မန္တလေး; MLCTS: manta.le: [máɰ̃dəlé]) is the second-largest city in Myanmar
column2: after Yangon. Located on the east bank of the Irrawaddy River
column3: 716 km (445 mi) north of Yangon
column4: the city has a population of 1

column1: Mandalay was founded in 1857 by King Mindon
column2: replacing Amarapura as the new royal capital of the Konbaung dynasty. It was Burma's final royal capital before the kingdom's annexation by the British Empire in 1885. Under British rule
column3: Mandalay remained commercially and culturally important despite the rise of Yangon
column4: the new capital of British Burma. The city suffered extensive destruction during the Japanese conquest of Burma in the Second World War. In 1948
column5: Mandalay became part of the newly independent Union of Burma.

column2: Mandalay is the economic centre of Upper Myanmar and considered the centre of Burmese culture. A continuing influx of
mostly from Yunnan
column3: since the late 20th century
column4: has reshaped the city's ethnic makeup and increased commerce with China. Despite Naypyidaw's recent rise
column5: Mandalay remains Upper Burma's main commercial
column6: educational and health center.

column1: The city gets its name from the nearby Mandalay Hill. The name is probably a derivative of a Pali word
column2: although the exact word of origin remains unclear. The root word has been speculated to be maṇḍala (မဏ္ဍလ)
column3: referring to circular plains or Mandara
column4: a mountain from Hindu mythology.When it was founded in 1857
column5: the royal city was officially named Yadanabon (ရတနာပုံ
column6: [jədənàbòʊɰ̃])
column7: a loan of the Pali name Ratanapūra (ရတနပူရ) "City of Gems." It was also called Lay Kyun Aung Myei (လေးကျွန်းအောင်မြေ
column9: "Victorious Land over the Four Islands") and Mandalay Palace (မြနန်းစံကျော်

column1: Like most former (and present) capitals of Burma
column2: Mandalay was founded on the wishes of the ruler of the day. On 13 February 1857
column3: King Mindon founded a new royal capital at the foot of Mandalay Hill
column4: ostensibly to fulfill a prophecy on the founding of a metropolis of Buddhism in that exact place on the occasion of the 2
column5: 400th jubilee of Buddhism.

column1: The new capital city site was 66 km2 (25.5 sq mi) in area
column2: surrounded by four rivers. The plan called for a 144-square block grid patterned citadel
column3: anchored by a 16 square block royal palace compound at the center by Mandalay Hill. The 1020-acre (413-hectare) citadel was surrounded by four 2
column5: 666 ft) long walls and a moat 64 m (210 ft) wide
column6: 4.6 m (15 ft) deep. At intervals of 169 m (555 ft) along the wall
column7: were turrets with gold-tipped spires for watchmen. The walls had three gates on each side
column8: and five bridges to cross the moat. In addition
column9: the king also commissioned the Kuthodaw Pagoda
column10: the Pahtan-haw Shwe Thein Ordination Hall
column11: the Thudamma zayats or public houses for preaching Buddhism and a library for the Pāli Canon.

column2: the former royal palace of Amarapura was dismantled and moved by elephants to the new location at the foot of Mandalay Hill
column3: although construction of the palace compound was officially completed only two years later
column4: on Monday
column5: 23 May 1859.For the next 26 years
column6: Mandalay was to be the last royal capital of the Konbaung Dynasty
column7: the last independent Burmese kingdom before its final annexation by the British Empire. Mandalay ceased to be the capital on 28 November 1885 when the British conquered the city
column8: looted the Pitakataik (Royal Library) and sent Thibaw Min and his queen Supayalat into exile

column1: While Mandalay would continue to be the chief city of Upper Burma during the British colonial rule
column2: the commercial and political importance had irreversibly shifted to Yangon. The British view on the development of Mandalay (and Burma) was mainly with commercial intentions. While rail transport reached Mandalay in 1889
column3: less than four years after the annexation
column4: the first college in Mandalay
column5: Mandalay College
column6: was not established until 40 years later
column7: in 1925. The British looted the palace
column8: with some of the treasures still on display in the Victoria and Albert Museum
column9: also renaming the palace compound Fort Dufferin and used it to billet troops.

column2: Mandalay was the centre of Burmese culture and Buddhist learning
column3: and as the last royal capital
column4: was regarded by the Burmese as a primary symbol of sovereignty and identity. Between the two World Wars
column5: the city was Upper Burma's focal point in a series of nationwide protests against the British rule. The British rule brought in many immigrants from India to the city. In 1904–05
column6: a plague caused about one-third of the population to flee the city.

column2: Mandalay suffered the most devastating air raids of the war. On 3 April 1942
column3: during the Japanese conquest of Burma
column4: the Imperial Japanese Army Air Service carried out an extensive assault. The city was in effect defenseless as its firefighting resources were weak
column5: having been lost in earlier bombing
column6: it had no anti-aircraft capacity
column7: and the British RAF had by now withdrawn all its aircraft to India. Three-fifths of Mandalay's houses were destroyed and 2
column8: 000 civilians were killed. Many residents also fled when the city was under Japanese occupation from May 1942 to March 1945. The palace citadel
column9: which had been turned into a supply depot by the Japanese
column10: was in turn burnt to the ground by Allied bombing; only the royal mint and the watch tower survived. (A faithful replica of the palace was rebuilt in the 1990s.)

column1: After the country gained independence from Britain in 1948
column2: Mandalay continued to be the main cultural
column3: educational and economic hub of Upper Burma. Until the early 1990s
column4: most students from Upper Burma went to Mandalay for university education. Until 1991
column5: Mandalay University
column6: the University of Medicine
column7: Mandalay and the Defence Services Academy were the only three universities in Upper Burma. Only a few other cities had "Degree Colleges" affiliated with Mandalay University that offered a limited number of subjects. Today
column8: the city attracts a fraction of students as the military government requires students to attend their local universities in order to reduce concentration of students in one place.

column2: Mandalay celebrated its centennial with a festival at the foot of Mandalay Hill. Special commemorative stamps were issued.During Ne Win's isolationist rule (1962–1988)
column3: the city's infrastructure deteriorated. By the early 1980s
column4: the second largest city of Burma resembled a town with low-rise buildings and dusty streets filled mostly with bicycles. In the 1980s
column5: the city was hit by two major fires. In May 1981
column6: a fire razed more than 6
column12: 000 people homeless.Fires continue to plague the city. A major fire destroyed Mandalay's second largest market
column15: and another major fire in February 2009 destroyed 320 homes and left over 1600 people homeless.The 1980s fires augured a significant change in the city's physical character and ethnic makeup. Huge swaths of land left vacant by the fires were later purchased
column17: many of whom were recent immigrants from Yunnan. The Chinese influx accelerated after the current State Peace and Development Council came to power in 1988. With the Burmese government turning a blind eye
column18: many Chinese immigrants from Yunnan (and also from Sichuan) poured into Upper Burma in the 1990s and many openly ended up in Mandalay. In the 1990s alone
column21: 000 Yunnanese are estimated to have migrated to Mandalay. Today
column22: ethnic Chinese people are believed to make up about 40%–50% of the city's population that is nearly the same as the natives
column23: and are a major factor in the city's doubling of population from about 500
column24: 000 in 1980 to one million in 2008. Chinese festivals are now firmly embedded in the city's cultural calendar. There is a complaint that Mandalay is becoming little more than a satellite of China and that the British colonial romance of old Mandalay is long gone.The Chinese are largely responsible for the economic revitalization of the city centre
column27: and returning the city to its role as the trading hub connecting Lower Burma
column29: China and India. The Chinese dominance in the city center has pushed out the rest to the suburbs. The urban sprawl now encompasses Amarapura
column30: the very city King Mindon left some 150 years ago. Mandalay celebrated its 150th birthday on 15 May 2009
column31: at precisely 4:31:36 am.Despite the rise of Naypyidaw
column33: Mandalay remains Upper Burma's main commercial
column34: educational and health center. In October 2018
column35: Mandalay was ranked by CIO Asia as number fifth among the top 10 cities in Southeast Asia in the process of becoming a smart city for ASEAN Smart Cities Network.

column1: Mandalay is located in the central dry zone of Burma by the Irrawaddy river at 21.98° North
column2: 96.08° East
column3: 80 meters (260 feet) above sea level. Its standard time zone is UTC/GMT +6:30 hours.

column1: Mandalay lies along the Sagaing Fault
column2: a tectonic plate boundary between the India and Sunda plates. (The biggest earthquake in its history
column3: with a magnitude of 7
column4: occurred in 1956. The devastation was greatest in nearby Sagaing
column5: and it came to be known as the Great Sagaing Quake.)

column1: Bodies of water near Mandalay are Mandalay Kantawgyi
column2: a small lake and Irrawaddy River to the west of the city.

column1: The rain shadow of the Arakan Mountains is so powerful that the city qualifies as having a hot semi-arid climate (Köppen climate classification: BSh)
column2: although it does border on a tropical wet and dry climate (Köppen climate classification: Aw). Mandalay features noticeably warmer and cooler periods of the year. Average temperatures in January
column3: the mildest month
column4: hovers around 21 °C or 69.8 °F while the hottest month
column5: April
column6: averages 31 °C or 87.8 °F. Mandalay is very hot in the months of April and May
column7: with average high temperatures easily exceeding 35 °C or 95 °F. It is not uncommon to see high temperatures surpass 40 °C or 104 °F during these two months in the city. Mandalay also features wet and dry seasons of nearly equal length
column8: with the wet season running from May through October and the dry season covering the remaining six months. The highest reliably recorded temperature in Mandalay is 48.0 °C (118.4 °F) on 24 April 1975 while the lowest is 7.6 °C (45.7 °F) on 26 December 1999. There is considerably more diurnal temperature variation in the dry season than the wet season.

column2: which literally means "inimitable vihara"
column3: is also one of the well known sights. The original structure was destroyed by a fire in 1890 though the masonry plinth survived. The reconstruction project was started by the government on 2 May 1995 and completed in June 1996.

column1: Buddha's Replica Tooth Relic Pagoda:  One of the Buddha's Sacred Replica Tooth Relics was enshrined in the Mandalay Swedaw Pagoda on Maha Dhammayanthi Hill in Amarapura Township. The pagoda was built with cash donations contributed by the peoples of Burma and Buddhist donors from around the world under the supervision of the State Peace and Development Council. The authorities and donors hoisted Buddha's Replica Tooth Relic Pagoda Mandalay's Shwe Htidaw (sacred golden umbrella)
column2: Hngetmyatnadaw (sacred bird perch vane) and Seinhpudaw (sacred diamond bud) on 13 December 1996.

column1: Kuthodaw Pagoda (The World's Biggest Book):  Built by King Mindon in 1857
column2: this pagoda modeled on the Shwezigon Pagoda at Nyaung-U
column3: is surrounded by 729 upright stone slabs on which are inscribed the entire Tipiṭaka as edited and approved by the Fifth Buddhist council. It is popularly known as "World's largest book" for its stone scriptures.

column1: Kyauktawgyi Pagoda: Near the southern approach to Mandalay Hill stands the Kyauktawgyi Buddha image built by King Mindon in 1853–78. The Image was carved out of a huge single block of marble. Statues of 80 arahants are assembled around the Image
column2: twenty on each side. The carving was completed in 1865.

column1: Mahamuni Buddha Temple: The image of Gautama Buddha at Mahamuni Buddha Temple is said to have been cast in the life-time of the Gautama Buddha and that the Buddha embraced it seven times
column2: thereby bringing it to life. Consequently
column3: devout Buddhists hold it to be alive and refer to it as the Mahamuni Sacred Living Image. Revered as the holiest pagoda in Mandalay
column4: It was built by King Bodawpaya in 1784. The image in a sitting posture is 12 feet and 7 inches (3.8 m) high. As the image was brought from Rakhine State
column5: it was also called the Great Rakhine Buddha. The early morning ritual of washing the Face of Buddha Image draws a large crowd of devotees every day. The Great Image is also considered as the greatest in Burma next to Shwedagon Pagoda.

column1: Mandalay Hill:  The hill has for long been a holy mount. Legend has it that the Buddha
column2: on his visit
column3: had prophesied that a great city would be founded at its foot. Mandalay Hill
column4: 230 metres high
column5: provides a view of the city and surrounding countryside. The construction of a motor road to reach the hill-top has already been finished.

column1: Mandalay Palace:  The whole palace complex was destroyed by a fire during World War II. The palace walls
column2: the city gates with their crowning wooden pavilions and the surrounding moat
column3: "Mya-nan-san-kyaw Shwenandaw"
column4: were rebuilt using forced labor. A model of the Mandalay Palace
column5: Nanmyint-saung and Mandalay Cultural Museum are located inside the Palace grounds.

column1: Shwenandaw Monastery: known for its wood carvings
column2: it was a part of the old palace. In 1880 it was moved by King Thibaw to its current site close to Atumashi Monastery.

column1: U Bein Bridge : known for the oldest and (once) longest teakwood bridge in the world. It was constructed when the capital of Ava Kingdom moved to Amarapura .
Yadanabon Zoological Gardens: A small zoo between the Mandalay Palace and Mandalay Hill. It has over 300 species and is notably the only zoo to have Burmese roofed turtles.

The Mandalay Region Government is the government for Mandalay Region including Mandalay City. The Mandalay City Development Committee (MCDC) is municipal organization for Mandalay City. The Mandalay District consists of seven townships.

Mandalay's strategic location in Central Burma makes it an important hub for transport of people and goods. The city is connected to other parts of the country and to China and India by multiple modes of transportation.

Mandalay International Airport (MDL) was one of the largest and most modern airports in Myanmar until the modernization of Yangon International Airport in 2008. Built at a cost of US$150 million in 2000
column2: it is highly underused; it serves mostly domestic flights with the exception of those to Kunming and to/from Bangkok and Chiang Mai
column3: with daily flights on Air Asia and Bangkok Airways. The airport has come to represent the military regime's propensity for bad planning and penchant for white elephant projects. Myanmar's recent opening stance on tourism means the airport is now receiving a growing number of visitors from Bangkok and Chiang Mai.

column1: The airport is far from the city
column2: 45 km (28 mi) on a modern highway. Before the construction of this airport
column3: Mandalay Chanmyathazi Airport was the main airport of the city. The airport serves some flights to Myanmar towns.

Mandalay literally is at the center of Burma's road network. The highway network includes roads towards:

column2: Mandalay–Mogok–SiU–Bhamo Road

column1: Lower Burma– Yangon-Mandalay Expressway and AH1Most stretches of these highways are one-lane roads in poor condition.
As the government allows only a few thousands of vehicles to be imported each year
column2: motor transportation in Burma is highly expensive for most of its citizens. Most people rely on bicycles
column3: motorcycles and/or private and public buses to get around. Back in the 2000s
column4: the most popular car in Mandalay was the 1982/83 Nissan Sunny pickup truck. Because of its utility as a private bus or taxi
column5: the two-and-a-half-decade old model still had strong demand and heady prices to match—from K10 million to K14 million (US$8
column6: 000 to US$11
column7: 000) in mid-2008. To get around severe import limits
column8: people of Mandalay had turned to illegally imported and hence unregistered (called "without" in Burmese English) motorcycles and cars despite the government's periodic confiscation sprees then.In March 2008
column10: 000 registered motor vehicles plus an unknown number of unregistered vehicles. Although the number of cars in a city of one million is low
column11: traffic in Mandalay is highly chaotic as thousands of bicycles and (unregistered) motorbikes freely roam around all the lanes of the streets. Unlike in Yangon where motorbikes
column12: cycle rickshaws and bicycles are prohibited from entering downtown and busy areas
column13: in Mandalay it is anything goes. In 2018
column14: as part of Mandalay Smart City initiatives
column15: new traffic lights with internet-connected sensors have been installed by Mandalay City Development Committee to manage traffic at junctions.

column1: A 2007 estimate by the UN puts Mandalay's population at nearly 1 million. The city's population is projected to reach nearly 1.5 million by 2025. While Mandalay has traditionally been the bastion of Bamar (Burman) culture and populace
column2: the massive influx of ethnic Han-Chinese in the last 20 years has effectively influenced the ethnic-Bamar majority there. Although many native ethnic Han-Chinese could not get Burmese citizenship
column3: the foreign-born Yunnanese can easily obtain Burmese citizenship cards on the black market. Ludu Daw Amar of Mandalay
column4: the native journalist had said it felt like "an undeclared colony of Yunnan". Today
column5: the percentage of ethnic Han-Chinese
column6: estimated at 50% of the city (with the Yunnanese forming an estimated 30% of Mandalay's population)
column7: is believed to be nearly same as that of the ethnic-Bamar. A sizable community of Indian immigrants also resides in Mandalay.

column1: Burmese is the principal language of the city while Chinese dialects are increasingly heard in the city's commerce centers such as Chinatown and Zegyo Market. English is a third language
column2: only known by some urban people.

column1: Mandalay is Burma's cultural and religious center of Buddhism
column2: having numerous monasteries and more than 700 pagodas. At the foot of Mandalay Hill sits the world's official "Buddhist Bible"
column3: also known as the world's largest book
column4: in Kuthodaw Pagoda. The styles of Mandalay Buddha Images and Buddha Statues were many since King Mandon
column5: who was a devout Buddhist
column6: and had filled Mandalay with them and through the years Mandalay Buddhist art became established as the pure art of Myanmar. There are 729 slabs of stone that together are inscribed with the entire Pāli canon
column7: each housed in its own white stupa.

column1: Much of the media in Mandalay – like elsewhere in Burma – comes from Yangon. The city's non-satellite TV programming comes from Yangon-based state-run TV Myanmar and military-run Myawaddy
column2: both of which provide Burmese language news and entertainment. Since December 2006
column3: MRTV-4
column4: formerly a paid channel
column5: has also been available in Mandalay. Mandalay has two radio stations. Naypyidaw-based Myanmar Radio National Service is the national radio service and broadcasts mostly in Burmese (and in English during specific times.) Semi-state-run Mandalay City FM (87.9FM) is the Mandalay metropolitan area's pop culture oriented station.The military government
column6: which controls all daily newspapers in Burma
column7: uses Mandalay to publish and distribute its three national newspapers
column8: the Burmese language Myanmar Alin and Kyemon and the English language New Light of Myanmar. The state-run Yadanabon is published in Mandalay and serves the Upper Burma market.

column1: The Mandalay Daily newspaper is published by Mandalay City Development Committee since 1997 November 30.
Mandalay's sporting facilities are quite poor by international standards but are still the best in Upper Burma. The 17
column2: 000 seat Bahtoo Stadium was the largest in Upper Myanmar before the construction of Mandalarthiri Stadium and hosts mainly local and regional association football and track-and-field tournaments. Since May 2009
column3: professional football has arrived in Mandalay
column4: with Yadanabon FC representing the city in the newly formed Myanmar National League
column5: the country's first professional football league.

column2: a new stadium
column3: Mandalarthiri Stadium was built to host the Women Football matches of 27th SEA Games and became the largest stadium in Mandalay and Upper Myanmar.

column1: Mandalay is the major trading and communications center for northern and central Burma. Much of Burmese external trade to China and India goes through Mandalay.
Among the leading traditional industries are silk weaving
column2: tapestry
column3: jade cutting and polishing
column4: stone and wood carving
column5: making marble and bronze Buddha images
column6: temple ornaments and paraphernalia
column7: the working of gold leaves and of silver

column1: Chinese immigrants have increasingly dominated Mandalay's economy since the imposition of sanctions by the United States and the European Union in the 1990s.
Mandalay has the best educational facilities and institutions
column2: after Yangon
column3: in Burma where state spending on education is among the lowest in the world. Students in poor districts routinely drop out in middle school as schools have to rely on forced "donations" and various fees from parents for nearly everything – school maintenance to teachers' salaries. Many wealthy Mandalay parents enroll their children in the city's English language private schools for primary and secondary education and Chinese and Singaporean universities for university education. Some wealthy Chinese families also send their children to "cram schools" where students study for entrance exams into Chinese universities from 6am to 8am
column4: then to government high schools from 9am to 3pm
column5: and finally preparation classes for Singapore GCE O levels from 4pm to 9pm.

column1: For the rest of the students who cannot afford to go abroad for studies
column2: Mandalay offers Upper Burma's best institutions of higher education. There are over 15 universities including Sasana University. The city's University of Mandalay
column3: University of Medicine
column4: Mandalay
column5: University of Dental Medicine
column6: Mandalay
column7: Mandalay Technological University and University of Computer Studies
column8: Mandalay are among the nation's most selective universities.

column1: The general state of health care in Burma is poor. The military government spends anywhere from 0.5% to 3% of the country's GDP on health care
column2: consistently ranking among the lowest in the world. In 2005
column3: the public health care system of Mandalay Region with over 7.6 million people consisted of slightly over 1000 doctors and about 2000 nurses working in 44 hospitals and 44 health clinics. Over 30 of the so-called hospitals had less than 100 beds. Although health care is nominally free
column4: in reality
column5: patients have to pay for medicine and treatment
column6: even in public clinics and hospitals. Public hospitals lack many of the basic facilities and equipment.

column1: Nonetheless Mandalay remains the main health care center for Upper Burma as almost all of large public hospitals and private hospitals are in Mandalay. The city has ten public hospitals and one hospital specializing in traditional Burmese medicine. For a semblance of adequate health care
column2: the well-to-do from Upper Burma go to private hospitals and clinics in Mandalay. For more advanced treatments
column3: they have to go to Yangon or abroad. The wealthy Burmese routinely go abroad (usually Bangkok or Singapore) for treatment.

column1: Rudyard Kipling wrote a poem called "Mandalay" (1890)
column2: which is the origin of the phrase "on the road to Mandalay". In 1907
column3: the poem was set to music by Oley Speaks as On the Road to Mandalay. Speaks' version was widely recorded. Among the best known renditions is the one by Frank Sinatra on Come Fly With Me.

column1: The large hotel/casino/convention center Mandalay Bay in Las Vegas is named for the city
column2: despite the fact that the city is 500 kilometers from the nearest bay
column3: perhaps in reference to the line in Kipling's poem
column4: "An' the dawn comes up like thunder outer China 'crost the Bay! "

column1: George Orwell was stationed at Mandalay for a time while working for the Indian Imperial Police in Burma

column4: was based on his experiences in Burma. He also wrote a number of short non-fiction essays and short stories about Burma
